Text: Some examples: Someone asks for some data, or poses a quantitative problem, that can only truly be answered with tables of numbers. It would be nice to able to embed within questions and answers a small box, the width of the answer space but with its own scroll bars, to make the data feel part of the page. There could be an export to excel button for people to do further work with the data. I imagine this would play havoc with the SE systems for dealing with predominantly text based answers, but for this site, on Economics, I feel it could be important.

Migration paths are only enabled for fully graduated sites.  In extreme cases the moderators can migrate a question and users can flag them so mods see it.  But keep in mind that a migration path is a ways off.

Wasn't talking about a full-blown migration path, I was talking about guidelines for moderator-based migration which it's my understanding can happen the moment Economics hits public beta. A lot of things are a ways off, but I already know that we'll be sending quite a few back and forth and I just wanted to establish guidelines beforehand :)
Joel specifically referred to the _private beta_.  Basic questions are usually tolerated more once the site is established.

I teach economics at a university (and FWIW have earned a Ph.D. in the subject).  As I read the question, it was asking about how a firm might influence the demand curve.  This is beyond ECON 101 and gets into some interesting issues.  I could, for example, re-pose the exact question in a fancy way (and answer it in similar fashion).  I wonder if wording the question (& answers) in a more **inaccessible** way would render it acceptable, or convince others that it is sufficiently complicated?  From what I've seen today, this was (IMHO) one of the more interesting and less obvious ones.
Makes sense.  And it may be useful to let a borderline question sit and see what kind of answers it gets before making a judgment.
Migration to beta sites is normally discouraged, but either way I think these guidelines are useful for scope.

Hm, did you see stats.SE? Posting tables as a code (i.e. indented) works just fine. Also you can output the data using `dput` in R if you really need it for further analysis. And from R you can output it in Excel, if you really, really want to. In the worst possible scenario you can put the link to the data in question.
Since you mentioned my "model breaking down" question -- it *wasn't* mentioned in my E201 / Econ 101 course, and in fact was the largest part of my field of study!

About your last question, I agree, that really is the borderline of economics and psychology. However, check out papers by the Cornell economist Kaushik Basu on this subject. Decision theoretic explanation of the phenomenon.
@AarthiDevanathan That's exactly the problem with one person applying their experience to determine the whole site :P
It's really not personal.  I don't make the rules, and you and others can vote to re-open your question if you feel strongly about it.  It's not the end of the world.

"Don't often occur?" When was the last time you read Krugman's column in the NY Times? He regularly disses people he disagrees with, using words like "stupid" and clueless". http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/10/if-banks-are-outlawed-only-outlaws-will-have-banks/ http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/11/stocks-flows-and-fuzzy-math/ http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/07/way-off-base-2/

great reply, Jason. I think that if a question is designed to elicit a political response, it should be removed. Otherwise, it should stay and responders should take care to make statements backed by well-known models.

@mehaase Krugman the columnist has nothing to do with Krugman the economist. If Krugman wrote a paper in the same vein as he writes NYT articles, he would get skinned. Well, now that he's a Nobel laureate he won't, but you know what I mean.
I'm sorry if it seemed I'm taking it personally. I hope you see though that my question was about economics and had nothing to do with psychology whatsoever.

@mehaase user68 is right--Krugman's column is a forum for his personal opinion, economics.SE isn't.  We disagree often, but we **understand** why the other person came to his conclusions.  Disagreements usually relate to whether/when assumptions are reasonable--hardly the stuff of drama.  The environment in which you practice economics must be quite different from mine.

I agree with the OP. Even when attending real-life seminars I get sometimes a feeling "Gee, people are actually studying this?..". Economics is a very broad domain. It could make things harder choosing what is off-topic but the method suggested by the OP is a quick and efficient one.
I don't think we can say your professor's a slouch if he manages to have his own Wikipedia article.

Economics can answer normative questions, but the norms are usually specified.  So, given a certain goal (say, "reduce smoking"), economics usually has something to say about how to go about it.  But, the idea that one should reduce smoking is the stuff of policy, not economics.  Hence, answers are normative or positive, but most questions would not be.

@JasonB, I guess I understand what you're saying, and that is, "academics don't get into petty arguments in the classroom -- but they might at a party". But this site is going to get lots of questions from people who are not research economists… it will get a lot of questions redirected from the Personal Finance SE, for example, where people are asking questions about current events and things they heard somebody say on NPR or the O'Reilly Factor. Are we going to close questions just because the asker is not phrasing it in a way that research economists can answer cleanly?

I like your answer, but I think it's also an indicator of how easy it is to slip into bias by accident. E.g. I think the term "goldbug" is a pejorative (so does Wikipedia) and shouldn't be used in an academic discussion. I saw a question on money velocity equation yesterday that defined the equation and then drew conclusions from it, failing to observe that V is not constant. I think it would be a failing of the site to vote up an answer on a canonical money supply question that fails to even consider the rate of change of V.

@JasonB, don't you mean the other way around? We can tolerate normative questions, but not normative answers? "How does a junk food tax work?" is not normative, but "Is a junk food tax a good idea?" is normative. Either question is fine, as long as the answers are not normative, e.g. "Any tax will be split by the producer and the consumer…blah blah blah".

@mehaase Yes, too bad comments can't be edited.  An answer to the second question need only start with "assuming the policy goal is to reduce consumption of saturated fats..." without closing the question.  Like it or not, economists are asked such questions all the time, and discipline is required in the answer.  But, the SE culture seems to place the burden on questions (questions are closed, not answers), so it will be interesting to see how this site sorts itself out (I have some doubts that it can be done).

@mehaase The site was originally aimed at experts and professionals, but it looks like most of the concerns surround questions from the laity.   I think the site will fail or succeed on how these non-professional questions are handled, if at all (along whether or not the question of the bounds of economics can be sorted--a tall order).

With all due respect Joel, what exactly is your econ background? If a student took 223 and learned about hashing, does that make hashing a trivial subject? Clearly not. Even if the concept is straight forward, two CS people could easily discuss the merits of different schemes (chaining, open addressing, etc), good hash functions, when not to hash, etc. Similarly, although econ 115 will cover supply and demand, that doesn't make it a trivial issue. There's a lot of complexity in deriving demand curves and understanding nuances, and no intro course can cover that.

I think, looking at the FAQ, that at this point in the beta, a question that is too basic is classed as "off-topic". At this point in the beta, for a question to be on-topic, it has to be beyond economics 101 - http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/9/remember-exemplary-questions
@EnergyNumbers Ah, I forgot that basic = offtopic. Possibly because the *topic* of this question was just fine, it was the question itself that was basic.
none! that's why I'm not participating in the site! (Other that to close things that would have been questions on the final in the Econ 101 class I took)
"If people are misunderstanding your question, the problem lies in your question. You can't fix the people, so fix your question."
Agreed. Determining whether Bitcoin or Economics is the subject of the question should be the basis. Unfortunately that's not always trivially done.
There are several other sites with similar policies.  CS Theory, Philosophy, etc.

Although I'm not saying it should apply here, both Theoretical Computer Science and Theoretical Physics contain the notion of questions that are "too basic."  Also certain questions may be appropriate for the site but nevertheless be too basic for a private beta.
Ah, so it's not so much that we don't want lower-level questions at all, we just don't want them during private beta?
About your last point: fair enough, point taken. Apologies to everyone for being a douche!

As for the rest, most questions in economics also have a behavioural answer, a psychology based answer, etc. If I was to find papers which answered those questions I wouldn't ask the question. Much better that responders think twice before concluding that the only answers lie outside the domain of economics. For example, in that particular question, I do reference "papers in voting theory". If one doesn't realize that such papers are actually econ papers, it'd be better to refrain from commenting.

The only question I can come up with NOT in categories 1-4 is to clarify or explain a concept that is not explained clearly in it's original presentation. (E.g. a paper that uses an uncommon term but doesn't define it.)

I've extended my answer to Joel's question to address this.  Basically, I don't believe for a second that experts will be any more OK with a beginner question posted a day after private beta ends rather than a day before.  If the site really is for experts, it needs to cater to them consistently.  This mixed message nonsense makes the site unusable for anyone.

Not just collegiate questions, but also questions that may arise from watching mainstream coverage of economics. (That was my original interest in this site, a place for intelligent discussion about macroeconomics for people who can't make sense of what they see on the news.)

I like it although it may work better as a strapline?  My understanding is that a pitch is a bit deeper and needs to address a common problem, potentially steering things too.  In the initial stages we're going to attract academic economists and gold-bugs.  Too much of that and it becomes over-intellectual and tremendously bogged down.  How do we attract the layman who has an interest but not necessarily the intellectual background (or confidence) to enter such an environment?

Re (3) - Aren't questions you'd ask a colleague / fellow economist EXACTLY the sort of questions we do want here? And re (2) original research isn't necessarily bad - if the answer is just a new synthesis of existing work
Great suggestion! I think this would be especially helpful in facilitating higher-level research questions on this site. Does anyone know how this can be turned on?
@EnergyNumbers: I agree with EnergyNumbers: questions which you would want to ask a fellow economist are exactly the kind of question you'd want to ask here.

Can you please elaborate on what you mean by "heavy dependency"? I think this would be a great way to encourage the types of research questions we would like to see in SE. Economic theory becomes extremely mathematical at higher levels, so it would be essential to have this tool available. In my opinion, not having this tool would hinder the growth of the community. Could you describe the disadvantages of this dependency so that we users are more informed? Then perhaps we can have a more meaningful discussion of whether it is a good idea, and maybe even have a vote or something?

It means that for every single page, whether there are formulas on the page or not, the MathJax files would need to be downloaded if the user didn't have them cached.  The MathJax files are pretty large relatively.

I would agree with Ryan that absence of LaTeX might hinder the growth of community. I for one could not recommend this site for any of my econometrician colleagues. This is of course not a big deal, but somehow I feel that if LaTeX is not available then there will be no mathematical content in this site, which would be a pity. But that is my personal opinion.
Hm if layman gives valuable insight, why it should be discarded?

A good point about the existence of the Research Economics proposal potentially causing confusion (or even "cannibalization" of M.S. or Ph.D. level economists, to over-dramatize a bit, away from the Economics site), note this recently updated, quite  active Area 51 discussion re viability of the Research Economics proposal  http://discuss.area51.stackexchange.com/questions/2024/merge-economics-and-research-economics
Succintly put. I've just gone through and torched the lot
I like it ... :)

I would like to also see tags indicate that a question is a graduate-level or above kind of question. There were a bunch of us who had a pre-beta stackexchange site for "Research Economics" and I think there's a fear among us that this site will get flooded with basic questions that stray too far from economics (ie., "Will interest rates rise or fall in 2012?")

@dchandler - for now, in the private beta, all questions are supposed to be of a decent calibre: if you do see any questions that are the sort of thing an 18-year old might ask, close them as off-topic: http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/9/remember-exemplary-questions

@dchandler, tag for graduate level will not work. Stats.SE and math.SE do not have these tags, though they have every reason for that. Homework tag on the other hand would work perfectly, since usually elementary questions are homework questions. The question "will interest rates rise or fall in 2012?" on the other hand is far from basic. As far as I know, nobody can answer it accurately.

@EnergyNumbers and mpiktas: Yea, I think you guys are right. I'm sort of new to this. Hopefully the average content will be high enough that it doesn't matter. I like the idea of a homework tag or something that I could add to an ignore list (not to say I wouldn't answer good homework questions!)

i agree with you. Stats questions which do not involve mathematical results explicitly (limit theorems, specific efficiency results) should be in the econ forum. It is impossible for a statistician to tell you which method to use without knowing the specific context. Plus, statisticians would not know what the usual practice in economics is regarding the question.

I think I'm the "guilty" party on adding those questions. One bit of 2-cents I'd like to add is that the way econometricians or applied, empirical economists use statistics is *vastly* different than statisticians. One of my good friends is a Ph.D. student in statistics and he laughs at many of the procedures we economists employ. For example, economists never spend much time understanding when standard assumptions on the error term are violated. Economists have tended to sweep this under the rug (for better or worse) ever since Huber-White standard errors.

Exactly, but they may not use the "appropriate" academic jargon (a good thing, IMO) - we need an appropriate response to the experts who go, "Oh, but why didn't you just say 'comparative advantage' and have done?"
Which are usually 'normative' questions and we should potentially have a good definition which allows us to close any questions entering that space...
We should put this in FAQ and then send people there. A good rule would be to give at least wikipedia definitions when using some specific terminology.
Recent Nobel prize winner Ch. Sims has [some strong words](http://sims.princeton.edu/yftp/EmetSoc607/AppliedBayes.pdf) for this kind of behaviour.
@mpiktas - nice. Love the single-sentence conclusion: "Lose your inhibitions: Put probabilities on parameters without embarrassment."
+1 Thanks for bringing this to meta (and for your clarity) so that we can, hopefully, get it sorted for future reference.

I would say that if the rules change that my post also would need to either be removed or be referenced(or grandfathered).   I am also not calling for proof just a reference to what you are referring to. If you want a Graduate level research site then you should have graduate level requirements.  Would a professor really let you get away with referring Gini coefficient statistics without citing your reference in a paper? (I would prefer a more relaxed site but the site has been deemed graduate level + and this will help to achieve that)

Good point.  Can you clarify what is meant by "all answers should be able to be referenced"?  To me, that implies that answers should be precisely worded so that they are falsifiable, but not necessarily that a citation is required.  Am I reading that correctly?  I think the requirement of falsifiability (e.g. precise wording) would address many of @chad's concerns.

It is a public site I Agree and it is a good thing.  By that ambiguity I simply meant that valid answers should be able to be referenced.  As such a reference requirement is not really all that encumbering.  And the requirement sets a specific criteria that can be evaluated objectively for the acceptance of both question and answers.
@JasonB I updated the original post - I simply meant that any question or answer of value should be able to be referenced thus the requirement is not unreasonable.

@Chad, I think we are much on the same page.  I strongly agree that questions should be worded precisely, and a big role of the community will probably be to help edit questions to make them more precise.  As for student papers, it is sometimes subtle.  On an exam or quiz, I certainly accept well-known trends/facts without citation.  On a class paper I often do not (except in obvious cases, and what is 'obvious' is a bit subjective).  I've put out un-cited facts in journal articles BTW (and even have had citations removed by editors because I was citing "simple facts").

The migration option is there for mods, it's just discouraged to migrate **to** beta sites except in exceptional circumstances.  Migrating from us to Stats is OK, though the mods-to-be would do well to check with the mods of the other site first unless they have a really good handle on the scope of the other site.
You can always find an hack to reference for any argument you want to have. Let them just ask.

I never said references were easy to find.  And that is kind of the point.  To enforce some effort go into not just Answering but asking as well.  It gives an objective standard to which all questions and answers can be expected to attain.  It will help to achieve High quality questions and answers to a site for Graduate + level economists.
Five days in, it's a bit early to know what questions are going to be asked frequently.

I would also like to point out one other thing.  If we impose the requirement now and it proves to be too burdensome then it can always be relaxed or even removed.  It will be much harder to impose more stringent standards when there those who have been around and refuse to change.  \n
I personally am all for the every man's economist site.  But unless that is the site you want to end up with an objective standard needs to be implemented.
More likely it'll achieve an empty website. There is nothing wrong with the way the inequality question was asked. You think there is no such thing? Answer and provide all the references you want.

@EnergyNumbers That's not what is meant by the FAQ.  The FAQ is not a section to list questions that are asked frequently *on* the site (if it were then I would agree with your point).  The FAQ is for frequently asked questions *about* the site.  In particular, it should contain specific information about what types of questions are welcome, as well as perhaps what types of questions are not welcome.

I understand. And, ISTM that it's too early to tell what questions are asked frequently about the site. Other than those quesitons that are common to all Stacks. I don't think we've had a single duplicated question on meta yet - so no question is frequently asked. Similarly, looking at the other meta questions, for most tags, it's too early to tell. For page design, it's too early to tell. For deciding who the moderators are, it's too early to tell. We do have an open question on elevator pitch, and I think now is a good time to tackle that one.

I think, as we close / re-open / delete questions on the main site, we'll get closer to being able to say what questions are and aren't welcome on the main site. Though maybe we're starting to see some clues now, re fiat currency and goldbugginess
+1. Nice start!

yes, please do answer your own question. Ooh, by the way, please could you update the title of that question too, so that it is a meaningful question? Would prefixing it with "What would be a better ..." capture the gist of the question?
I think questions > graduate level are acceptable here, btw

Haha, true -- hmmm how do I type the symbol for infinity in the comment? Does \infty work?

Ok, I'll go update the Q and the title..very soon. Already spent too much time tonight on here :) Thanks!

It seems to me that if unorthodox views are sound then they should be welcome, and if they are not sound then it would be beneficial for the experts here to refute them.  So in either case it seems there is value in unorthodox views.
I am not questioning is the topic ok.  The question as asked needs to be refined sourced and limited to a specific topic that would not fill 6 volumes in order to answer well.

The original question made a claim of increasing income disparity and wanted to know if anyone had written about potential solutions.  I was asking for clarity on the question because it was far to broad and made a claim of statistical veracity.  All i was asking for was some statistics (like the ones provided by another poster) to be included in the question so that there was something directly to address.  The reworded question is much more on topic.  Check the revision history to see the original question and I think you will understand.

I agree that we should not be a site *exclusively* "for professionals"... but we definitely want to make sure professionals stay. On the original stackoverflow, newbie programmers can ask questions and derive value from the site. But their doing so doesn't reduce value for the so-called professionals. Similarly, some standards should be kept high. I disagree that exact references should be required. After all, explanations of code aren't always fully written solutions and merely pointers. The pointers of course should be in the direction of substantive sources.

I'd definitely like to see LaTeX, I wrote a fuller answer below... but I genuinely feel that to get the super-users, they will want to know that LaTeX can be used. After all, mathematics is the language of a lot of economics. Would you ever open a math or statistics site without LaTeX? Likewise, you shouldn't open an econ site without it.

@EnergyNumbers The format of the FAQ is already set. People *will* ask what types of questions they can post, and they *will* post off-topic questions.  The FAQ can evolve, but right now it should contain what we've already decided about on- and off-topic.  If we really have nothing to put there then no, we aren't ready to go public.
This answer should perhaps be moved to a new meta post.

It's a bit problematic: there are few economics questions that are too simple--most economics ANSWERS are too simple.  Consider a "simple" question: "Where do prices come from?"  The answer might be simple or complex depending on the audience.  Perhaps many of these issues could be resolved by assuming questions are seeking the graduate level answer, and not the ECON 101 answer?
There might indeed be a high correlation between a question being bad and it being a "goldbug/bitcoin question," but that need not always be the case.
I think the questions we've had so far illustrate so very well why this minimum standard is so necessary http://economics.stackexchange.com/search?tab=newest&q=closed%3a1
@EnergyNumbers I don't think that link without explanation illustrates much of anything; could you please elaborate?

Many of those questions deserved to be closed for reasons independent of what we're discussing here.  The two you cited that are most relevant (about [currency of the future](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/121/currency-of-the-future) and [infinitely divisible money](http://economics.stackexchange.com/questions/252/is-infinitely-divisible-fixed-quantity-currency-affectable-by-hoarding)) are at their hearts asking about economies involving different assumptions.  Perhaps they need to be reworded, but I think limiting the site to adherents of certain economic viewpoints is limiting.
Do you have a particular example in mind that wouldn't be too basic?  Most can be answered with a link to Wikipedia, I would think.  Stuff like "How long did the Great Depression last?"

Unfortunately, I doubt most of our future questioners will have quite as specific a need as in your example, and so we will still need some way to deal with the majority of data questions. Check out the quant.SE data question to see how it can work (in theory) with a little bit of editing and moderation.
If JEL assigns an entire top-level code to it, then I assume there are plenty of non-basic questions. Just check out the vast literature with that code.

@Tal I did, it's a mess.  You have on big list with broad categories and no details, and a bunch of other random answers of varying quality as well.  I don't believe for a second that people won't have specific needs for data, they're not just looking for masses of data with no intent.

Questions about the analysis of history and the like is obviously on topic, so I assumed you're asking about historical facts. If that's not the case, please elaborate in the question.  (Side note: Vast literature indicates to me that it's trivial to find information oneself.)

At least 51 people seem to think the list is helpful (most of those up-votes came after my editing).  If I were a moderator, I'd also go in and delete all the other posts that have now been made irrelevant.  I'm open to suggestions on how to deal with this problem, but please don't delude yourself into thinking that *only* people with very specific needs will come to this site asking for help.  If this is not handled properly up-front, we will **constantly** be dealing with people asking "where can I find quarterly GDP?" and other such simple questions.

@MatthewRead I am talking about analysis of economic history, and its not obvious to me that is on topic given the existence of history.SE (why not post an answer and let community decide?).  Vast literature indicates that academics think there are many interesting questions to address.  Surely there are some more questions that SE users may have that have not been addressed by the literature.  Also, literature recommendations are a large part of the value added potential of this site.

@TalFishman There are over 200 **closed** questions on Stack Overflow with a score that high.  Those sort of resource posts always get votes, and I don't view their votes as an indicator of anything other than imagined helpfulness.  Basic questions are already off-topic, and SE is not for people who are unable to form a Google search.  I don't think this sort of post is useful to the people who can really contribute to the site.
There are precisely zero closed or open other questions with a score that high on quant.SE.  You cannot compare SO (over 16 million monthly visits) to quant.SE (under 14,000 monthly visits).
@Tal Some of those questions have fewer views than the Quant question and are perfectly comparable.  Votes are not an indicator of suitability, and I stand by all my other points regardless.
Perhaps a tad arrogant ;p but a good answer - many historical events have economic origins or consequences, so worth including.

This website is not deigned to be a platform for research (i.e.: a bespoke journal). It is a swap-shop for pre-existing knowledge and understanding. The questions I highlighted were not from people interested in Economics, they were from video-gamers who will put better Economists off (and who are amply catered for elsewhere).

it's not a question of limiting it to particular viewpoints - it's about a certain minimum threshold of quality. Adherents to various heterodoxies have so far not generated content of appropriate quality here. That's not entirely surprising, but it doesn't **have** to be the case - I know of at least one living educated, informed Austrian-schooler who's able to produce quality content, so it is possible. I look forward to seeing content of such quality here, but you'll understand why I'm not holding my breath.
Goldbug is a pejorative term.

@PatrickBeardmore There are real economists doing work on virtual currencies, i.e. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Castronova. Therefore, there is a body of work that we can reference to answer these questions.

@EnergyNumbers Your bias is evident. You don't like Austrian theory and you don't think it belongs on this site, unless it's written by the 1 person you know who's not an idiot? I'm not sure why this is even relevant to virtual currencies.

@mehaase. That's not what I wrote. Nor what I meant. It is possible to have an intelligent comment from an Austrian economist. It's even conceivable that we might get an intelligent comment from a goldbug. However, there's been a strong correlation on this site, and on the web as a whole, to date, between bad questions and heterodox views (including goldbugs and virtual currencies)

@PatrickBeardmore Video gamer questions are off-topic regardless of their specific nature. That doesn't mean there can't be valid questions on the subject of web-based currencies, and questions should be *questions*, not discussions of or the publication of research.  Researchers are capable of posting real questions I'm sure :P
I'll add that I don't think this is perhaps something covered in econ 101.
+1 complete agreement
I agree! I'm not sure how I would write that. You should take a crack at it and get everyone's feedback.

Hi @RebeccaChernoff, I was wondering if there was any update on the ability to turn on LaTeX. I think many of us feel that this is necessary to attract the expert-level contributors we hope to see on the site.
I think this is a great idea! The shorter the better!

I think this is a really great idea. How are these usually written? Should one person take ownership of this, create a first draft and then get comments? Should there be a call for everyone to add their 2 cents and then have aggregation? As an economist, I am very new to this "public good" thing and don't know how to behave.

Cross-posting by actually posting the same question on multiple sites is discouraged.  You don't have to explicitly search every SE site for a similar question, though research is expected before asking any question (check out the tooltip when you hover over the upvote button on the main site).
Thanks for letting us know - that's great news.

Indiana University is my alma mater! :D Also, though less scholarly, [Cory Doctorow](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cory_Doctorow) has also written extensively about online/gaming economies and their weaknesses/strengths, though usually in his fiction. While his agenda is more social justice than economic, it's still worth noting. :)
There were some suggestions, but how do we go about implementing them? Who can edit the FAQ?
Let me give this some thought - I want to track down one of the comments on normative questions I've read and see if that offers any insight.
Yeah, agreed, all useful stuff - most of the job of the working economist is tracking our data and explaining our results; I think even questions on visualisations should be useful.

I say we should hold off until the site is in public beta before we enable MathJax. I think we have a lot of good content here as we are, Greek letters are enabled in the text field, and MathJax means *every single page* loads slower. At the moment, it strikes me that the cost of MathJax (in the short term) is far higher than its benefit. Once we start having more traffic and experience a rightward demand-shift for MathJax, we can (and should) enable it.

Well, one effect that I have noticed (in the few minutes since I started browsing this site) is that there are an awful lot of posts with messed up formatting because they are using $ to denote dollars, and inadvertantly going into and out of tex mode. It does seem unfortunate that an economics site would reserve the $ sign for going into math mode.

FWIW, I was able to use MathJax without any instructions.  I'd assume that most people who have made it through an econ graduate program recently will have had at least one class in which problem sets had to be formatted using LaTeX.
So questions no longer need to be graduate level questions?
@Chad - AIUI, that's right. But they shouldn't be answerable by general reference either. And questions should show some research effort, and be useful to others as well as the OP.
...and "Personal Finance & Money" has http://money.stackexchange.com

@EnergyNumbers Could you clarify what you mean regarding, "based on one or more true premises"?  Obviously you want to exclude questions like, "What caused the Great American Recession of late 1990s?" since that is based on the false premise that there was such a recession.  However, it's not clear whether you wish to exclude hypothetical questions or questions that otherwise deal with non-standard economic assumptions.

I mean that it shouldn't be based on false premises. The assumptions that the question makes should be true. The basis presented within the question should reflect the actuality. A question such as "what would have happened to the 1970s oil crisis if Apollo 11 had discovered that the moon was not made out of cheese, but was in fact made out of kerosene" is a bad question.
See http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/86/use-as-the-inline-mathjax-delimiter-rather-than for a feature-request to apply the electronics.SE solution here too

And there's the Numerical Modelling and Simulation proposal too, currently in commitment : http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1907/numerical-modeling-and-simulation?referrer=3_PccF1xXZWENXVbMz64bg2
Oh, and as an aid to the general reader, I will rephrase this as a question to go in the main part...

Sure, that's certainly the main reason - I'm trying to go a little deeper, however, because otherwise we are going to be permanently weeding these out.  We need a way to draw normative questions towards reasoned questions and answers.  I want to establish whether the only response is closing the questions, or whether we can "prove" why normative questions can't be answered.  In other words, is asking this question in itself normative?
+1 for the closing paranthetical comment

Good point.  And raises this: How, on the open web, will we prevent non "graduate and professional economists" from asking questions?  If we can't then we need a way to handle them with respect and tolerance.
This might help shed some light: http://blog.stackoverflow.com/2011/02/are-some-questions-too-simple/

Good point.  How about Tim Harford (Undercover Economist and the rest of his ouvre)?  His books are more what I had in mind (I realise, though, that Freakonomics is what gave life to this topic in the first place). And what would we call it?

Thanks Turukawa.  I think I failed to appreciate the dynamic nature of SE.  As I understand your answer, the community standards are not something that is dictated (or voted) explicitly, but they are determined by up/down/close votes and comments.  Thus, the standards may evolve over time and therefore it is not necessary for there to be rules to cover each case.  So, as [Justice Stewart](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_know_it_when_I_see_it) might say:  I can't specify which questions are too basic, but I know it when I see it.   Or perhaps I've misunderstood.
@EnergyNumbers - thanks! I think that pretty much settles it.
Again, fair point, which leads to the question - how should we tag these types of questions?  Lateral thinking?

Yes, exactly, which is why questions that I've posed (like the normative question one) are essential for this early signalling phase.  All of this has to be handled fairly sensitively otherwise it just becomes a flame war.  "We" - as the members with the most rights - can agree how we want to assist the site but we certainly can't stop people going in directions most useful for themselves.
I like it, but "monetary economics" is a branch of macro, so it might be confusing.
yeah, tricky, isn't it? And non-money-economics just sounds like barter to me.
+1 This is pretty close (but not quite) what what I'm thinking of without being too long.   I assume these can be easily changed in the future if necessary.
@Turukawa  The first book of this genre I recall is "Hidden Order: the Economics of Everyday Life", but that's a bit long for a tag.
yup, I think the limit is 25 characters - so it's just too long.

Good insight!  In fact, the unifying theme of many of these types of analyses is a focus on rational behavior--that simply assuming rationality goes a long way even in non-market contexts. Perhaps a slight adjustment to **"rational-behavior"** then?  We can ignore the fact that some people call this "amateur sociology". :-)
the trouble is that Revealed Preference is already a category of study within market research, and it's largely within the framework of conventional economics.

It is but it comes close to what we're all wondering about: a way of using economic research techniques to reveal the way in which people unconsciously use non-financial price-discrimination to value and act on non-financial choices.
hmmm. How's **non-financial-preferences** as a possibility?
has the benefit of being practical

It seems that there are only three of us in this discussion (@Turukawa, you and me).  Since this answer is +2, might I suggest that we go with this tag for now? A synonym can be added later if something better comes up.  It might be better to have a tag NOW than to have a better tag in 2 weeks.
I've done that now, and put a tag edit in the queue for it

As you may have inadvertantly proven, it may not matter what we want if that is what interests people.  Now that we have questions like this on the site, and they've attracted this sort of interest, likelihood is we will be getting a lot more (like the chewing gum question which immediately followed yours)...

Fair point. It would be very disappointing if we do not attract more of the Graduate / Professional Economist type questions that are the initial focus. (Clearly there are not enough of this audience on the site now based on which questions are open.). I agree that we should still aim to maintain a high quality bar where the original litmus test for each question still applies.

Our difficulty at the moment is in encouraging new users while still allowing the enthusiastic amongst us to pounce on every question to up our tallies so more of us can have editing and maintenance rights.  All the problems of a new site...

I think you're stumbling in during the early teething stages of the site and I'm sorry you're getting such a rough landing (although, you could check out my questions - and the response to it - on normative economics to see real rough). The difficulty is that a theory may be normative and untangling it can be very complex to answer within the context of this site. First the nature of the question needs to be understood and that does require reflection from the asker; that process is more tricky in a format that requires Question -> Answer.
@Turukawa - no problem! I'm fine with that. :-)

There actually are some existing Stack Exchange sites that are exclusively for academics/experts; see [theoreticalphysics.se] and [cstheory.se]. However, there have been several others that were originally intended to be expert-centric sites, but ended up being more general. I guess we'll have to wait and see which category this site falls into.
don't like the tag
don't like the tag

+1 I fully support the aggressive revision suggestion; I think economics questions are (and will be) very google-able, and the better those questions are, the better the site traffic will be. Which, in turn, will be self-fulfilling.

Looks broadly fine to me. I think that econo-stats questions have fared pretty badly on this site so far (there are 4 or 5 with no answers), though, and would be better placed over on stats.SE

Update: The question has since been closed. It helps when the community issues downvotes, close votes and flags (as appropriate).  The new [proposed faq](http://meta.economics.stackexchange.com/questions/138/text-for-the-faq) contains language that I think would allow us to handle these questions immediately instead of requesting revision ("professional tone" and "premises backed up by formal literature").

I think both you and @JasonB have the more moderate view which agrees with my own, so happy to act in terms of "moderator of last resort" and also that this becomes less of an issue as the number of users with 500+ rep increases.

that's a shame: our daily visitors count had just started to rise, it seemed.

I agree - the current system for tracking progress and providing feedback is broken; the [Area 51 page](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics) tries to give you an overview of where you stand, but completely fails at indicating *progress* (or a lack thereof). I don't want to get into the habit of *nagging* sites that are doing their best, but some sort of regular status update is something we owe you - this is as much of a wake-up call for us as anything. So lemme just say again, that I do - we all do - greatly appreciate the time and effort you've put in, and stay tuned...

I'm not averse to redirection, but at present we've no real support for it - I'm currently pushing for a way to automatically redirect requests for questions that have been migrated prior to closure to their destination, which would be extremely helpful. If you get something up and running, adding a link to the Area 51 page is possible. Keep in mind also that we're working on a way to structure site creation differently, with the eventual goal of turning "shutdown" into something more akin to a living archive - this may at some point provide a more useful resurrection.
Please ask the destination site before migrating a question. I just removed a question from OnStartups that was migrated there, because it was not on topic for our site.

@ZulyGonzalez I agree that it would be best to coordinate with the receiving site via meta.  But in that ideal world, we would have more than a few days' warning that the site is closing.  I'm afraid the only way to get this done will be for us to migrate questions and let the receiving site decide if they want to keep them.  Is what you are requesting a policy of SE, or just your personal preference?

I'm not an SE employee, so I can't speak on their behalf. As far as I know it's not an SE policy, it's just the courteous thing to do. I understand your current constraints (and I'm sorry your site is being closed), but it's not very productive to dump a bunch of questions to another site that may or may not be a good fit for that site (I'm not suggesting this happened). There were 2 Qs migrated to our site from here, neither of them were a good fit for us. One was way off-topic, so I deleted it, which reversed the migration. (The question is back on your site.)

The other was slightly off-topic, and I'm still debating what to do with it. My suggestion would be to simply compile a list of the Qs you guys think are potential candidates for migration to OnStartups, then posting a question on our meta site listing those Qs. Give it say 1-2 days to compile the list, and 1-2 days for our community to respond. Or you can just ping me. I'm more than happy to take a look at any Qs that may be possible candidates for us.

A living archive would a LOT easier than trying to figure out where questions "should" go.  Could you then revive a version from before we started the migrations (i.e. a frozen version of the site from immediately prior to the shutdown announcement?)

I suspect some questions here may simply not be on topic at any other SE sites because they are so purely about economics. Alas, for the same reason, those questions may well be concentrated among the best ones for _this_ site. :(

Ps. I'll try to take a closer look at the math / game theory questions later today, and maybe try to pick out some other migration candidates too if I spot them. (I would've done it sooner, but my monitor broke down and I've had to use this laptop with a postcard-sized screen, which is not exactly the best possible tool for sorting through a lot of pages.)
9 days to evict? I always disliked Stackexchange for it's hostility and cockyness.

@Turukawa not without the datadump - which isn't there, as far as I can see. And I don't have time this week to write an API scraper to grab the site as it is now, either. I can see how it's against StackExchange's commercial interest to facilitate setting up a site that would compete with what they envisage to be some future econ.SE site.

I've collected a list of possible math.SE migration candidates [here](http://meta.math.stackexchange.com/a/4076), but let's give others there a little time (say, half a day at least) to comment first.
Ps. Apparently, [not everyone on money.SE feels quite so accommodating](http://meta.money.stackexchange.com/a/494). :(

So, a portion of the migrated questions may ultimately be closed & deleted.
Granted, but at least there'll be a discussion about it, and not sure I've transferred more than 30 in total, maybe 15-20 to money...
Excellent, thanks! That's exactly the kind of help I was hoping for when I started this thread.

No worries. Hopefully, people who like to ask and answer questions about behavioral economics and related topics will feel welcome at Cognitive Sciences - SE. If we fire them across and they get reverted, so be it.
Thanks Jason, will do my best but it's also a busy week for me.  I figure we'll lose most of them and I'll be hated all across the SE universe for "random and unsolicited migrations" ;p
@ChrisW.Rea Thank you VERY much.  I've gone ahead and migrated those--given your status on that site, I trust that you have a pretty good sense for what will be on-topic.

Thanks @Turukawa.  I'm sure the folks on the other sites will understand.  I just migrated a bunch of questions, so maybe I'll take most of the heat.  As long as the person requesting the migration seems like they'd know what's on topic on the target site (high rep or mod), I seriously doubt we'll be too far off the mark.

@Turukawa I am currently the only _active_ mod on OnStartups (a site that is much bigger than this one), and up until a week ago I had a full-time job **and** a part-time job. Please be considerate of other people's time. My time is no less valuable than yours. It's not an issue of being unwilling to take your questions, but I find it astonishing that it appears as though you want the mods from the other sites to do your job for you. Please not that it is not our responsibility to dig through your site (which is unfamiliar to us) in the hopes of finding a few on-topic questions.

@Turukawa Please see [this official answer](http://meta.answers.onstartups.com/a/865) from a Stack Exchange employee, which backs up my decision not to accept a litany of mostly off-topic questions from Econ.SE. Also, it is worth mentioning that you do not have to migrate every single question on this site to another SE site. It is expected that most will not be on topic on any other SE site. The number of questions you migrate should be small compared to the number of questions currently on the site.

@ZulyGonzalez I wouldn't expect many questions to be migrated to OnStartups (and I don't think two questions constitute a "litany").  The questions being migrated for the most part are those that have been identified by very high-rep users of the target site or mods on the target site.  Please don't mischaracterize what is being done here--indeed, I'd be surprised if your site is affected again.
Hi how do I download the damp for this site? Your link is confusing, offers to download data only for September 2011 and it seems not to be for Economics at all! Help!

@daniel: sorry for the confusion - the dump won't be created until the site actually *closes.* At that point, it'll be linked to from this site's [Area 51 page](http://area51.stackexchange.com/proposals/1618/economics).

@JasonB I'm not mischaracterizing. 100% of the questions migrated to Onstartups (a total of 3), were migrated without our site being involved. None of our mods or our high rep users identified any of the questions migrated to us as valid migrations. The questions just magically showed up on our site. After I saw what was happening I came here to ask that you please consult with our site if you plan to continue migrating questions to our site, because continuing down this path is going to result in unnecessary work for our mods.

I believe that is a fair request, however, it resulted in @Turukawa falsely characterizing it as "OnStartups has been unwilling to take our questions". I'm sorry, but we are not going to accept off-topic questions. However, we're more than happy to accept any that are ontopic for us. And yes, I agree that 3 is not a lot, but that is thanks to the fact that I was proactive in stopping the flow of questions being sent our way. Again, if you find a question that you think may be a good fit for our site, I am more than happy to take a look at it.
Ilmari, thanks so much for all your support and help over the last few days.  Very much appreciated.  You ever make it over to the UK, we can go grab a coffee...
